metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Organic reactions and pathways, including equations, reactants, products, reaction conditions and catalysts (specific enzymes not required): synthesis of primary haloalkanes and primary alcohols by substitution; addition reactions of alkenes; the esterification between an alcohol and a carboxylic acid; hydrolysis of esters; pathways for the synthesis of primary amines and carboxylic acids; transesterification of plant triglycerides using alcohols to produce biodiesel; hydrolytic reactions of proteins, carbohydrates and fats and oils to break down large biomolecules in food to produce smaller molecules; condensation reactions to synthesise large biologically important molecules for storage as proteins, starch, glycogen and lipids (fats and oils)

substitution_definition.name: Substitution Reaction Definition
substitution_definition.correct: In a substitution reaction, an atom or group of atoms is replaced by another atom or group of atoms.

two molecules combine to form one larger.error: That describes condensation or addition, not substitution.
two molecules combine to form one larger.fix: Substitution means exchange: something leaves, something else takes its place.
two molecules combine to form one larger.action: Think: sub-stitute = replace. Like a substitute teacher replaces another teacher.

a molecule is broken into smaller pieces.error: That describes decomposition or hydrolysis, not substitution.
a molecule is broken into smaller pieces.fix: Substitution maintains the carbon skeleton. One group swaps for another.
a molecule is broken into smaller pieces.action: Count atoms before and after. The carbon chain stays intact in substitution.

atoms are added across a double bond.error: That describes addition reactions, not substitution.
atoms are added across a double bond.fix: Addition requires unsaturation. Substitution works on saturated compounds too.
atoms are added across a double bond.action: Check: is a double bond being broken? If yes, it's addition, not substitution.

persistent.gap: You're confusing substitution with other reaction types.
persistent.action: Make a table: substitution = replace, addition = add across C=C, condensation = join + lose H₂O.

halogenation_conditions.name: Alkane Halogenation Conditions
halogenation_conditions.correct: Alkanes react with halogens (Cl₂ or Br₂) under UV light to form haloalkanes via substitution.

heat.error: Heat alone won't initiate halogenation of alkanes.
heat.fix: UV light provides energy to break the X–X bond and start the chain reaction.
heat.action: Remember: UV light is essential for alkane halogenation. Heat works for other reactions.

acid catalyst.error: Acid catalysts are for esterification or hydration, not halogenation.
acid catalyst.fix: Halogenation of alkanes is a free radical reaction initiated by UV light.
acid catalyst.action: Match catalyst to reaction: acid = esterification, UV = halogenation.

aqueous solution.error: Aqueous conditions are for nucleophilic substitution of haloalkanes, not halogenation.
aqueous solution.fix: Halogenation uses pure halogen gas (Cl₂ or Br₂) with UV light.
aqueous solution.action: Aqueous NaOH converts haloalkanes TO alcohols. UV + Cl₂ makes haloalkanes FROM alkanes.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up conditions for different reaction types.
persistent.action: Create a conditions chart: halogenation (UV), hydration (acid, heat), esterification (acid, heat).

haloalkane_to_alcohol.name: Haloalkane to Alcohol Conversion
haloalkane_to_alcohol.correct: Haloalkanes react with aqueous metal hydroxides (NaOH, KOH) to form alcohols via substitution.

concentrated sulfuric acid.error: Concentrated acid is for dehydration of alcohols, not synthesis.
concentrated sulfuric acid.fix: To make alcohols from haloalkanes, use aqueous hydroxide (OH⁻).
concentrated sulfuric acid.action: OH⁻ attacks carbon, pushing out X⁻. Acid would do the opposite (remove OH).

ammonia only.fix: NH₃ gives -NH₂ (amine). OH⁻ gives -OH (alcohol). Different nucleophiles, different products.
ammonia only.action: Which group do you want? -OH needs OH⁻, -NH₂ needs NH₃.

UV light and water.error: UV + water won't work. You need a nucleophile (OH⁻).
UV light and water.fix: Metal hydroxides provide OH⁻ ions that can attack the carbon and displace the halogen.
UV light and water.action: UV is for halogenation. Nucleophilic substitution needs OH⁻, not just H₂O.

persistent.gap: You don't understand nucleophilic substitution reagents.
persistent.action: Learn: haloalkane + OH⁻ → alcohol, haloalkane + NH₃ → amine.

haloalkane_to_amine.name: Haloalkane to Amine Conversion
haloalkane_to_amine.correct: Haloalkanes react with ammonia (NH₃) to form primary amines via substitution.

aqueous sodium hydroxide.fix: To get -NH₂, you need a nitrogen source. NH₃ provides this.
aqueous sodium hydroxide.action: Check the product: -OH came from OH⁻, -NH₂ came from NH₃.

nitrogen gas.error: N₂ is unreactive. You need ammonia (NH₃).
nitrogen gas.fix: N₂ has a triple bond and is very stable. NH₃ has a lone pair and acts as a nucleophile.
nitrogen gas.action: N₂ won't react. NH₃ is the reactive nitrogen compound.

hydrochloric acid.error: HCl would not help synthesise amines from haloalkanes.
hydrochloric acid.fix: NH₃ attacks the carbon and displaces the halogen. HCl is actually a by-product.
hydrochloric acid.action: HCl is produced in the reaction, not used as a reagent.

persistent.gap: You're not matching reagents to products correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: want -OH? Use OH⁻. Want -NH₂? Use NH₃.

addition_definition.name: Addition Reaction Definition
addition_definition.formula: C=C + A-B → C-C with A and B attached
addition_definition.correct: In addition reactions, atoms are added across a C=C double bond, converting it to a single bond.

an atom is replaced by another atom.fix: Addition increases the number of atoms attached. Nothing is replaced.
an atom is replaced by another atom.action: Count atoms: addition adds atoms, substitution swaps atoms.

two molecules join and release water.fix: Addition has no small molecule released. Everything from both reactants is in the product.
two molecules join and release water.action: Is water released? If yes = condensation. If no small molecule lost = addition.

a molecule breaks into smaller pieces.error: That's decomposition or hydrolysis, not addition.
a molecule breaks into smaller pieces.fix: Addition builds up: double bond opens to accept new atoms.
a molecule breaks into smaller pieces.action: Addition makes bigger or same-size molecules, never smaller.

persistent.gap: You're confusing addition with other reaction types.
persistent.action: Key test: Does a C=C become C-C while accepting new atoms? That's addition.

hydrogenation.name: Hydrogenation Reaction
hydrogenation.formula: Alkene + H₂ → Alkane (Ni, Pd, or Pt catalyst)
hydrogenation.correct: Hydrogenation adds H₂ across a double bond using a metal catalyst (Ni, Pd, or Pt), converting alkene to alkane.

UV light.error: UV is for halogenation of alkanes, not hydrogenation.
UV light.fix: Hydrogenation needs a metal catalyst (Ni, Pd, Pt) to help H₂ react.
UV light.action: UV breaks Cl-Cl. Metal catalysts activate H-H for addition.

acid catalyst.error: Acid catalysts are for hydration, not hydrogenation.
acid catalyst.fix: Hydrogenation uses transition metal catalysts that adsorb H₂ and alkene.
acid catalyst.action: H₂SO₄ or H₃PO₄ = hydration. Ni/Pd/Pt = hydrogenation.

no catalyst required.error: H₂ doesn't react with alkenes without a catalyst.
no catalyst required.fix: The metal catalyst weakens bonds in both H₂ and the alkene, allowing reaction.
no catalyst required.action: Pure H₂ + alkene = no reaction. Add Ni = margarine from oils.

persistent.action: Memorise: hydrogenation = H₂ + metal catalyst (Ni, Pd, Pt). Used to make margarine.

hydration.name: Hydration Reaction
hydration.formula: Alkene + H₂O → Alcohol (H₃PO₄ or H₂SO₄, heat)
hydration.correct: Hydration adds water across a double bond using acid catalyst and heat, producing an alcohol.

metal catalyst.error: Metal catalysts are for hydrogenation, not hydration.
metal catalyst.fix: Hydration uses acid (H₃PO₄ or H₂SO₄) and heat to add H-OH across the double bond.
metal catalyst.action: Metal = hydrogenation (add H₂). Acid + heat = hydration (add H₂O).

UV light.error: UV light is for halogenation, not hydration.
UV light.fix: Hydration requires acid catalyst and elevated temperature (150-200°C).
UV light.action: UV is for radical reactions. Acid provides H⁺ for electrophilic addition.

base catalyst.error: Base-catalysed addition of water to alkenes is not the standard pathway.
base catalyst.fix: Acid (H₃PO₄, H₂SO₄) protonates the alkene, allowing water to add.
base catalyst.action: Industrial hydration uses phosphoric acid. It's an acid-catalysed process.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up catalysts for different addition reactions.
persistent.action: Chart: H₂ + metal = hydrogenation, H₂O + acid + heat = hydration, X₂ alone = halogenation.

esterification_definition.name: Esterification Reaction
esterification_definition.formula: Alcohol + Carboxylic acid → Ester + H₂O (H₂SO₄, heat)
esterification_definition.correct: Esterification combines an alcohol and carboxylic acid with acid catalyst and heat to form an ester and water.

base catalyst.error: Base would deprotonate the acid, preventing esterification.
base catalyst.fix: Acid (H₂SO₄) catalyses esterification. Base is for saponification (hydrolysis of esters).
base catalyst.action: Acid + heat = make ester. Base + water = break ester.

UV light.error: UV is for radical reactions like halogenation, not esterification.
UV light.fix: Esterification needs acid catalyst (H₂SO₄) and heat to proceed.

metal catalyst.error: Metal catalysts are for hydrogenation, not esterification.
metal catalyst.fix: Esterification uses concentrated sulfuric acid as a catalyst.
metal catalyst.action: Match catalyst: Ni/Pd/Pt = hydrogenation, H₂SO₄ = esterification.

persistent.action: Memorise: alcohol + carboxylic acid + H₂SO₄ + heat → ester + H₂O.

condensation_definition.name: Condensation Reaction
condensation_definition.formula: Two molecules → Larger molecule + small molecule (usually H₂O)
condensation_definition.correct: Condensation reactions join two molecules while releasing a small molecule, typically water.

a molecule breaks into smaller pieces.error: That's hydrolysis, the reverse of condensation.
a molecule breaks into smaller pieces.fix: Condensation builds up molecules. Hydrolysis breaks them down.

atoms add across a double bond.fix: Condensation joins molecules and releases water. Addition doesn't release anything.
atoms add across a double bond.action: Is water released? Condensation = yes, addition = no.

an atom is replaced by another.fix: Condensation combines two molecules. Substitution swaps groups on one molecule.
an atom is replaced by another.action: Condensation makes a larger product. Substitution keeps the same size.

persistent.gap: You're confusing condensation with other reactions.
persistent.action: Key test: Do two molecules join and release H₂O? That's condensation.

hydrolysis_definition.name: Hydrolysis Reaction
hydrolysis_definition.correct: Hydrolysis uses water to break larger molecules into smaller products. It's the reverse of condensation.

two molecules combine to form one larger.error: That's condensation, the reverse of hydrolysis.
two molecules combine to form one larger.fix: Hydrolysis breaks down. 'Lysis' means breaking apart. 'Hydro' means water.
two molecules combine to form one larger.action: Hydro-lysis = breaking with water. Think: water cuts the bond.

a molecule loses water to form a new pro.error: Losing water is condensation, not hydrolysis.
a molecule loses water to form a new pro.fix: Hydrolysis ADDS water to break bonds. Condensation REMOVES water to form bonds.

atoms are added across a double bond.fix: Hydrolysis breaks single bonds (like ester bonds, peptide bonds). Addition targets double bonds.
atoms are added across a double bond.action: Hydrolysis breaks apart already-formed molecules. Addition builds up from unsaturated ones.

persistent.action: Remember: hydro (water) + lysis (breaking) = using water to break molecules apart.

ester_hydrolysis.name: Ester Hydrolysis
ester_hydrolysis.formula: Ester + H₂O → Alcohol + Carboxylic acid (NaOH or enzyme)
ester_hydrolysis.correct: Esters are hydrolysed by water with NaOH catalyst (saponification) to produce an alcohol and carboxylic acid.

acid catalyst.error: Acid catalyses esterification (making esters), not hydrolysis.
acid catalyst.fix: Base (NaOH, KOH) catalyses ester hydrolysis. Acid pushes equilibrium toward ester.
acid catalyst.action: Acid + heat = make ester. Base + water = break ester.

UV light.error: UV is for radical reactions, not ester hydrolysis.
UV light.fix: Ester hydrolysis uses base (NaOH) or enzymes (like lipase).
UV light.action: Saponification = base-catalysed ester hydrolysis. Making soap!

high temperature only.error: Heat alone is slow. A catalyst is needed.
high temperature only.fix: NaOH or enzymes speed up ester hydrolysis. Excess water also helps.
high temperature only.action: Industrial hydrolysis uses NaOH. Biological uses enzymes (lipase).

persistent.gap: You're confusing esterification and hydrolysis conditions.
persistent.action: Esterification: acid + heat. Hydrolysis: base + water. They're reverse reactions.

transesterification.name: Transesterification for Biodiesel
transesterification.correct: Transesterification reacts triglycerides with methanol using NaOH catalyst to produce biodiesel (fatty acid methyl esters) and glycerol.

acid catalyst and high temperature.error: While acid can work, base (NaOH) is the standard industrial catalyst.
acid catalyst and high temperature.fix: NaOH in methanol is the common system. It's faster than acid-catalysed.
acid catalyst and high temperature.action: Industrial biodiesel uses NaOH as catalyst with excess methanol.

water as reagent.error: Water would cause hydrolysis, not transesterification.
water as reagent.fix: Transesterification uses alcohol (methanol), not water. Water is avoided.
water as reagent.action: Hydrolysis = water. Transesterification = alcohol. Very different.

metal catalyst.error: Metal catalysts are for hydrogenation, not transesterification.
metal catalyst.fix: NaOH (or KOH) catalyses transesterification for biodiesel production.
metal catalyst.action: Base catalyses ester exchange. Metal catalyses H₂ addition.

persistent.action: Key: triglyceride + methanol + NaOH → biodiesel (FAME) + glycerol. It's ester exchange.

protein_hydrolysis.name: Protein Hydrolysis
protein_hydrolysis.formula: Protein + H₂O → Amino acids (enzymes or HCl + heat)
protein_hydrolysis.correct: Proteins are hydrolysed by breaking peptide bonds, producing amino acids. Uses enzymes (pepsin, trypsin) or acid and heat.

base catalyst only.error: Base can work but acid (HCl + heat) or enzymes are more common.
base catalyst only.fix: Biological: enzymes (pepsin, trypsin). Lab: boiling in HCl.
base catalyst only.action: Digestion uses enzymes. Lab analysis often uses acid hydrolysis.

UV light.error: UV is for radical reactions, not peptide bond hydrolysis.
UV light.fix: Peptide bonds are hydrolysed by enzymes or acid + heat.
UV light.action: UV would denature proteins but not systematically hydrolyse them.

metal catalyst.error: Metal catalysts are for hydrogenation, not protein breakdown.
metal catalyst.fix: Protein hydrolysis uses biological catalysts (enzymes) or acid + heat.
metal catalyst.action: Enzymes are biological catalysts. Metals are for different reactions.

persistent.action: Proteins → amino acids via enzymes (biological) or HCl + heat (lab).

carbohydrate_hydrolysis.name: Carbohydrate Hydrolysis
carbohydrate_hydrolysis.correct: Polysaccharides (starch, glycogen) are hydrolysed to glucose by breaking glycosidic bonds. Enzymes catalyse this.

base catalyst.error: Base is for ester hydrolysis, not glycosidic bonds.
base catalyst.fix: Carbohydrate hydrolysis uses enzymes (amylase) or dilute acid + heat.
base catalyst.action: Amylase in saliva starts starch digestion. Enzymes are key.

metal catalyst.error: Metals are for hydrogenation, not carbohydrate breakdown.
metal catalyst.fix: Glycosidic bonds are hydrolysed by enzymes or dilute acid.
metal catalyst.action: Biological = enzymes. Lab = dilute acid + heat.

UV light.error: UV is for radical reactions, not glycosidic bond hydrolysis.
UV light.fix: Starch → glucose requires enzymes or acid, not light.
UV light.action: UV causes photochemical reactions. Hydrolysis needs water + catalyst.

persistent.action: Starch/glycogen → glucose via glycosidic bond hydrolysis. Enzymes (amylase) catalyse.

lipid_hydrolysis.name: Lipid (Triglyceride) Hydrolysis
lipid_hydrolysis.correct: Triglycerides are hydrolysed to glycerol and fatty acids by breaking ester bonds. Uses lipase enzyme or NaOH.

acid catalyst.error: Acid favours esterification. Base or enzymes favour hydrolysis.
acid catalyst.fix: NaOH (saponification) or lipase enzyme hydrolyses fats.
acid catalyst.action: Acid makes esters, base breaks them. Lipase does it biologically.

metal catalyst.fix: Fat hydrolysis uses NaOH (soap making) or lipase (digestion).
metal catalyst.action: Ni + H₂ = hydrogenation. NaOH + H₂O = hydrolysis.

UV light.error: UV is for radical reactions, not ester hydrolysis.
UV light.fix: Ester bonds in fats are hydrolysed by base or enzymes.
UV light.action: UV causes oxidation/rancidity, not controlled hydrolysis.

persistent.action: Triglyceride → glycerol + fatty acids. Lipase (biological) or NaOH (saponification).

condensation_proteins.name: Protein Synthesis by Condensation
condensation_proteins.formula: Amino acids → Peptide + H₂O (enzymes at ribosomes)
condensation_proteins.correct: Amino acids join via condensation reactions at ribosomes, forming peptide bonds and releasing water.

acid catalyst.error: Biological protein synthesis uses enzymes at ribosomes, not acid.
acid catalyst.fix: Ribosomes catalyse peptide bond formation in living cells.
acid catalyst.action: Acid works in labs for certain reactions. Biology uses ribosomes + enzymes.

addition reaction.error: Addition requires double bonds. Amino acids don't have C=C.
addition reaction.action: Peptide bonds form by condensation, releasing water.

substitution reaction.error: Substitution replaces atoms. Condensation joins molecules.
substitution reaction.fix: Two amino acids join and release H₂O. Nothing is replaced—they combine.
substitution reaction.action: Condensation = two become one, lose H₂O.

persistent.action: Amino acids condense: -COOH + H₂N- → peptide bond + H₂O. Happens at ribosomes.

condensation_carbohydrates.name: Polysaccharide Synthesis by Condensation
condensation_carbohydrates.correct: Glucose molecules join via condensation, forming glycosidic bonds and releasing water to make starch or glycogen.

addition reaction.error: Glucose doesn't have C=C double bonds for addition.
addition reaction.fix: Glycosidic bonds form by condensation between -OH groups on glucose.
addition reaction.action: Glucose has -OH groups that condense, not C=C for addition.

substitution reaction.error: Substitution replaces one group with another. Condensation joins molecules.
substitution reaction.fix: Two glucose molecules join, releasing H₂O. The molecules combine, not swap groups.
substitution reaction.action: Condensation = two become one polymer unit + H₂O.

hydrolysis.error: Hydrolysis breaks polysaccharides apart. Condensation builds them.
hydrolysis.fix: Condensation builds starch/glycogen. Hydrolysis breaks it back to glucose.
hydrolysis.action: These are reverse reactions. Condensation = build. Hydrolysis = break.

persistent.action: Build = condensation (−H₂O). Break = hydrolysis (+H₂O). They're opposites.

reaction_pathway_concept.name: Reaction Pathway
reaction_pathway_concept.correct: A reaction pathway is a sequence of reactions converting a starting material through intermediates to a final product.

a single reaction.error: A pathway involves multiple steps, not just one reaction.
a single reaction.fix: Pathways chain reactions together. Each step transforms the intermediate.
a single reaction.action: Count the arrows. Multiple arrows = pathway. One arrow = single reaction.

the reverse of a reaction.error: A reverse reaction is just one step. Pathways are multi-step sequences.
the reverse of a reaction.fix: Pathways plan how to build complex molecules step by step.
the reverse of a reaction.action: Alkane → haloalkane → alcohol → carboxylic acid = a pathway (3 steps).

equilibrium between products and reactan.error: Equilibrium is about one reversible reaction, not a sequence.
equilibrium between products and reactan.fix: Pathways are designed sequences of forward reactions to reach a target.
equilibrium between products and reactan.action: Equilibrium = one reaction going both ways. Pathway = series of reactions.

persistent.action: Draw: A → B → C → D. Each arrow is a reaction. Together they form a pathway to D.

addition.title: Mastering Addition Reactions
addition.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by comparing and contrasting addition reactions.

sentences.text: Hydrogenation and hydration both add to double bonds, but hydrogenation uses {{d1}} catalyst while hydration uses {{d2}} catalyst.

d1.tooltip: What type of catalyst does Ni, Pd, Pt represent?

d2.tooltip: H₃PO₄ or H₂SO₄ is what type of catalyst?

sentences.text: A common error is confusing hydrogenation with hydration. Hydrogenation produces an {{d3}} while hydration produces an {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Adding H₂ to alkene gives what?

d4.tooltip: Adding H₂O to alkene gives what?

sentences.text: Testing for unsaturation uses bromine water which {{d5}} when it reacts with alkenes. This is because Br₂ is {{d6}} across the double bond.

d5.tooltip: Bromine is orange-brown. What happens when it reacts?

d6.tooltip: What type of reaction occurs with the double bond?

sentences.text: Esterification is reversible. To favour ester formation, you can add excess {{d1}} or remove {{d2}} as it forms.

d1.tooltip: Le Chatelier: adding more reactant shifts equilibrium...

d2.tooltip: Removing which product shifts equilibrium forward?

sentences.text: Both peptide bonds and glycosidic bonds form by {{d3}}, but peptide bonds link {{d4}} while glycosidic bonds link {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: What type of reaction releases water?

sentences.text: Triglycerides contain three {{d6}} bonds formed when three {{d7}} condense with glycerol.

d7.tooltip: What long-chain molecules attach to glycerol?

hydrolysis.title: Mastering Hydrolysis Reactions
hydrolysis.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by comparing biological and industrial hydrolysis.

sentences.text: Biological hydrolysis uses {{d1}} as catalysts, while industrial hydrolysis often uses {{d2}} or {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What biological catalysts speed up reactions?

d2.tooltip: What is commonly used in lab hydrolysis?

d3.tooltip: Saponification uses what type of catalyst?

sentences.text: Glycogen releases glucose {{d4}} than starch during hydrolysis because glycogen has more {{d5}} providing more sites for enzyme attack.

d5.tooltip: What structural feature gives more enzyme access?

sentences.text: A student confuses hydrolysis with hydration. Hydrolysis breaks {{d6}} using water, while hydration adds water to {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: Does hydrolysis build or break molecules?

d7.tooltip: Hydration adds water across what type of bond?

pathways_biodiesel.title: Mastering Pathways and Transesterification
pathways_biodiesel.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of reaction pathways and biodiesel production.

sentences.text: Transesterification differs from hydrolysis because it uses {{d1}} instead of water, and the ester bonds are {{d2}} rather than broken.

d1.tooltip: What reacts with the triglyceride in transesterification?

d2.tooltip: What happens to the ester groups?

sentences.text: Water must be avoided in biodiesel production because it would cause {{d3}} instead of transesterification, producing {{d4}} instead of biodiesel.

d3.tooltip: What reaction occurs when water is present?

d4.tooltip: What are the products of triglyceride hydrolysis?

sentences.text: A complete pathway from ethane to ethyl ethanoate involves: ethane → {{d5}} → {{d6}} → ethanol, then esterification with ethanoic acid.

d6.tooltip: How is chloroethane converted to ethanol?

substitution_definition.title: Substitution Reactions
substitution_definition.content: Substitution reactions involve replacing one atom or group with another. The carbon skeleton remains intact while functional groups change.
keyPoints: Atom or group is replaced, not added
Carbon chain stays the same length
Examples: halogenation of alkanes, nucleophilic substitution of haloalkanes

halogenation_conditions.title: Alkane Halogenation
halogenation_conditions.content: Alkanes react with halogens (Cl₂, Br₂) under UV light to form haloalkanes. UV light provides energy to break the halogen bond and initiate a free radical chain reaction.
keyPoints: Longer alkanes give mixtures of isomers

haloalkane_to_alcohol.title: Haloalkane to Alcohol Conversion
haloalkane_to_alcohol.content: Haloalkanes undergo nucleophilic substitution with aqueous hydroxide ions (OH⁻) to form alcohols. The hydroxide replaces the halogen.
keyPoints: Halide ion is the leaving group

haloalkane_to_amine.title: Haloalkane to Amine Conversion
haloalkane_to_amine.content: Haloalkanes react with ammonia (NH₃) to form primary amines via nucleophilic substitution. Ammonia provides the nitrogen for the amine group.

addition_definition.title: Addition Reactions
addition_definition.content: Addition reactions occur when atoms are added across a C=C double bond, converting it to a single bond. The molecule becomes saturated.

hydrogenation.title: Hydrogenation
hydrogenation.content: Hydrogenation adds H₂ across a double bond using a metal catalyst (Ni, Pd, or Pt). This converts unsaturated compounds to saturated ones.
hydrogenation.formula: R-CH=CH-R + H₂ → R-CH₂-CH₂-R (Ni, Pd, or Pt)
keyPoints: Industrial use: making margarine from oils

hydration.title: Hydration of Alkenes
hydration.content: Hydration adds water across a double bond using acid catalyst and heat to produce an alcohol. H₃PO₄ or H₂SO₄ catalyses the reaction.

esterification_definition.title: Esterification
esterification_definition.content: Esterification combines a carboxylic acid and an alcohol with acid catalyst and heat to form an ester and water. It is a reversible condensation reaction.
keyPoints: Reversible—excess reactant or removing water favours products

condensation_definition.title: Condensation Reactions
condensation_definition.content: Condensation reactions join two molecules while releasing a small molecule (usually water). This is how biopolymers like proteins and starch are made.
keyPoints: Used to make proteins, polysaccharides, triglycerides

hydrolysis_definition.title: Hydrolysis Reactions
hydrolysis_definition.content: Hydrolysis uses water to break larger molecules into smaller products. It is the reverse of condensation and is essential for digestion.

ester_hydrolysis.title: Ester Hydrolysis (Saponification)
ester_hydrolysis.content: Esters are hydrolysed by water with base catalyst (NaOH) to produce an alcohol and carboxylic acid. This process is called saponification when making soap.

transesterification.title: Transesterification for Biodiesel
transesterification.content: Transesterification reacts triglycerides with methanol using NaOH catalyst to produce biodiesel (fatty acid methyl esters) and glycerol.

protein_hydrolysis.title: Protein Hydrolysis
protein_hydrolysis.content: Proteins are hydrolysed by breaking peptide bonds to release amino acids. Enzymes (pepsin, trypsin) catalyse this in digestion; acid + heat works in the lab.

carbohydrate_hydrolysis.title: Carbohydrate Hydrolysis
carbohydrate_hydrolysis.content: Polysaccharides (starch, glycogen) are hydrolysed to glucose by breaking glycosidic bonds. Amylase enzyme catalyses this in digestion.

lipid_hydrolysis.title: Lipid (Triglyceride) Hydrolysis
lipid_hydrolysis.content: Triglycerides are hydrolysed to glycerol and fatty acids by breaking ester bonds. Lipase enzyme catalyses this in digestion; NaOH works for saponification.

condensation_proteins.title: Protein Synthesis
condensation_proteins.content: Amino acids join by condensation at ribosomes, forming peptide bonds and releasing water. This builds polypeptide chains that fold into proteins.
keyPoints: Releases one H₂O per bond formed

condensation_carbohydrates.title: Polysaccharide Synthesis
condensation_carbohydrates.content: Glucose molecules join by condensation, forming glycosidic bonds and releasing water. This builds starch (plants) or glycogen (animals).
keyPoints: Glycogen is highly branched for quick glucose release

reaction_pathway_concept.title: Reaction Pathways
reaction_pathway_concept.content: A reaction pathway is a planned sequence of reactions converting a starting material through intermediates to a desired product. Efficient pathways minimise steps and waste.
keyPoints: Intermediate products become reactants for next step
